en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results_raw: in the old photographs, in the worn pages of antique magazines, and in the faded letters of a bygone era. The world has changed, but the essence of human experience remains the same. It's the same longing for connection, the same yearning for beauty, and the same quest for meaning that drove the artists and writers of the past to create their masterpieces. And it's this same essence that can be found in the dusty corners of our collective memory, waiting to be rediscovered and reinterpreted for a new generation. The problem is not that people have lost their taste for the finer things in life, but that they have become disconnected from the sources that once nourished their souls. They have forgotten how to slow down, how to appreciate the beauty in the mundane, and how to find meaning in the everyday. But it's not too late to change this. We can still seek out the old, the forgotten, and the overlooked, and breathe new life into them. We can still find the beauty in the worn and the weathered, and the magic in the mundane. And in doing so, we can recapture the essence of what once was, and make it relevant again for a new era.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results_raw: memoria de los que han vivido antes que usted. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo y auténtico, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la era digital. Los libros son más que simples fuentes de información; son portales a mundos imaginarios, refugios de la imaginación y guardianes de la sabiduría de las generaciones pasadas. Busque en los libros de poesía, en los poemas de amor y pérdida, en las historias de aventuras y fantasía, y en las obras de filosofía y ciencia. Busque en los libros que hayan sido escritos con pasión y dedicación, que hayan sido impregnados de la esencia de la humanidad. Busque en los libros que le hagan sentir que no está solo en su búsqueda, que hay otros que han caminado por el mismo camino y han encontrado la verdad que usted busca. Busque en los libros que le hagan sentir que la vida es un misterio profundo y hermoso, lleno de misterios y maravillas, y que cada página girada es una oportunidad para descubrir algo nuevo y emocionante. Busque en los libros que le hagan sentir que la imaginación es el límite de lo posible, y que cualquier cosa que se pueda imaginar es posible. Busque en los libros que le hagan sentir que la vida es un viaje de descubrimiento y exploración, y que cada libro es un mapa que le guía hacia lugares desconocidos y emocionantes. Busque en los libros que le hagan sentir que la lectura es una aventura, y que cada página es un nuevo capítulo en la historia de su vida.

Tal vez las bombas estuviesen allí, y los reactores veinte kilómetros, diez kilómetros, dos kilómetros cielo arriba durante un breve instante, como grano arrojado desde lo alto por la enorme mano del sembrador, y las bombas cayeron con espantosa rapidez y, sin embargo, con una repentina lentitud, sobre la ciudad que habían dejado atrás. es_second_half: aviso a sus apuntadores a ocho mil kilómetros por hora; tan fugaz como el susurro de una guadaña, la guerra había terminado. Una vez soltadas las bombas, ya no hubo nada más. Luego, tres segundos completos, un plazo inmenso en la Historia, antes de que las bombas estallaran, las naves enemigas habían recorrido la mitad del firmamento visible, como balas en las que un salvaje quizá no creyese, porque eran invisibles; sin embargo, el corazón es destrozado de repente, el cuerpo cae despedazado y la sangre se sorprende al verse libre en el aire; el cerebro desparrama sus preciosos recuerdos y muere.

en_first_half: As he stood there the sky over the house screamed. There was a tremendous ripping sound as if two giant hands had torn ten thousand miles of black linen down the seam. Montag was cut in half. He felt his chest chopped down and split apart. The jet-bombs going over, going over, going over, one two, one two, one two, six of
en_second_half: them, nine of them, twelve of them, one and one and one and another and another and another, did all the screaming for him. He opened his own mouth and let their shriek come down and out between his bared teeth. The house shook. The flare went out in his hand. The moonstones vanished. He felt his hand plunge toward the telephone.
en_results_raw: The sound was deafening, a cacophony of chaos that seemed to shake the very foundations of the house. Montag stumbled backwards, his vision blurring as the world around him disintegrated into a kaleidoscope of colors and sounds. The jet-bombs continued their relentless assault, a never-ending drumbeat of destruction that threatened to consume everything in their path. He felt himself being torn apart, his molecules scattered to the winds as the blast wave washed over him. The screams of the bombers grew louder, a chilling melody that seemed to come from all directions at once. Montag's mind reeled as he struggled to comprehend the sheer scale of the devastation. The house, once a sanctuary, was now a maelstrom of flames and smoke, its walls crumbling beneath the onslaught. He stumbled forward, his legs trembling beneath him, as he desperately sought to escape the inferno that was consuming everything in its path.

Montag, que había sido un ferviente defensor de la sociedad de control, comenzó a cuestionar su papel en la sociedad. ¿Qué era lo que estaba haciendo realmente? ¿Estaba protegiendo a la gente o estaba simplemente cumpliendo órdenes? La catarata de libros que había caído sobre él era un recordatorio de que había algo más en juego. Montag se detuvo en la escalera, mirando hacia abajo, y se preguntó si había llegado el momento de cambiar de bando. La oscuridad parecía estar llena de posibilidades, y Montag se sintió atraído por la incertidumbre. Mientras tanto, abajo en la calle, la Policía estaba cerrando el cerco alrededor de la casa, listos para capturar a cualquier persona que intentara escapar. La ciudad estaba en ebullición, y Montag se preguntó si estaría a tiempo de escapar de la tormenta que se avecinaba.

Ông ta nhìn xung quanh, và thấy rằng mọi người đều đang suy nghĩ về vấn đề này. "Chúng ta có thể đi tìm kiếm thêm diêm ở đâu đó," một người nói. "Nhưng ở đâu?" một người khác hỏi. Con la cerilla encendida, comenzó a caminar hacia la casa, su sombra proyectada en el suelo como una figura grotesca y fantasmagórica. La noche parecía estar llena de misterios y secretos, y Beatty se sentía atraído por ellos como un mosquito atraído a una llama. Mientras caminaba, su mente comenzó a vagar por los recuerdos del pasado, recordando momentos felices y tristes, y pensando en el futuro que se avecinaba. La noche era un misterio que lo envolvía, y Beatty se sentía parte de él, un pequeño pero importante pieza en el gran rompecabezas de la vida.

en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results_raw: in the old photographs, in the worn pages of antique magazines, and in the faded letters of a bygone era. The world has changed, but the essence of human experience remains the same. It's the same longing for connection, the same quest for meaning, and the same yearning for beauty that drove the artists and writers of the past to create their masterpieces. And it's this same essence that can be found in the dusty corners of our collective memory, waiting to be rediscovered and reinterpreted for a new generation. The problem is not that people have lost their taste for the finer things in life, but that they have lost touch with the past, and with each other. They are so caught up in their own little worlds, their own little screens, that they have forgotten how to appreciate the beauty of a well-crafted sentence, the power of a well-told story, and the magic of a well-made film. But it's not too late, Faber said, his eyes shining with a hint of hope. It's not too late to rediscover the things that truly matter, to reconnect with the world around us, and to find the beauty in the everyday. And it's in this rediscovery that we may just find the key to a more meaningful, more authentic, and more connected life.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. Busque en los libros de poesía, en los poemas de amor y pérdida, en las historias de aventuras y fantasía, y en las obras de filosofía y ciencia. Montag had heard that the owner, a gruff but fair man, had a soft spot for those in need, and he hoped to appeal to that side of him, to get a chance to buy some much-needed supplies without arousing suspicion. He took a deep breath, smoothing out his rumpled jacket and running a hand through his hair, trying to look as non-descript as possible, just another ordinary citizen going about his daily business, but his eyes kept drifting back to the gas station, his mind racing with the possibilities, and the risks, of what lay ahead.

en_first_half: And here was the gas station, its attendants busy now with customers. Approaching from the rear, Montag entered the men's washroom. Through the aluminium wall he heard a radio voice saying, “War has been declared.” The gas was being pumped outside. The men in the beetles were talking and the attendants
en_second_half: were talking about the engines, the gas, the money owed. Montag stood trying to make himself feel the shock of the quiet statement from the radio, but nothing would happen. The war would have to wait for him to come to it in his personal file, an hour, two hours from now.
en_results_raw: were shouting and laughing, their faces flushed with the excitement of the news, as they filled up the tanks of the sleek, black cars that sped by, their tires screeching on the asphalt. The radio voice continued to drone on, its words a steady hum in the background, as Montag stood there, frozen in the dimly lit washroom, his mind racing with the implications of the declaration. He thought of his wife, Mildred, and her love of the latest fashions, and how she would be glued to the television set, watching the news and the pundits, her eyes wide with wonder. He thought of his friend, Faber, and his love of books, and how he would be pacing back and forth in his study, his eyes scanning the pages of his precious volumes, searching for answers to the questions that now swirled in Montag's mind. And he thought of the firemen, his colleagues, and how they would be mobilizing, their trucks rumbling to life, their sirens blaring, as they set out to burn the books, to destroy the knowledge that threatened the very fabric of their society.

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”

es_first_half: —Ahora, vámonos río arriba —dijo George—. Y tengamos presente una cosa: no somos importantes. No somos nada. Algún día, la carga que llevamos con nosotros puede ayudar a alguien. Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
es_results_raw: será igual. Pero ahora, cuando nos vamos, dejamos atrás algo. Dejamos atrás la esperanza de que alguien pueda aprender de nuestros errores. Dejamos atrás la posibilidad de que alguien pueda encontrar la verdad en las historias que hemos vivido. Y dejamos atrás la oportunidad de que alguien pueda ver el mundo de una manera diferente, una manera que no es tan oscura y tan cruel como la nuestra. Pero no podemos dejar que eso nos detenga. No podemos dejar que la carga que llevamos con nosotros se vuelva demasiado pesada. Debemos seguir adelante, aunque sea difícil, aunque sea doloroso. Debemos seguir adelante, porque en algún lugar, alguien está esperando por nosotros. Alguien que puede aprender de nuestros errores, alguien que puede encontrar la verdad en nuestras historias, alguien que puede ver el mundo de una manera diferente. Y si no es así, entonces ¿para qué estamos aquí? ¿Para qué llevamos esta carga con nosotros? ¿Para qué seguimos adelante? La respuesta es simple: para que alguien pueda encontrar la luz en la oscuridad, para que alguien pueda encontrar la esperanza en la desesperanza. Y eso es lo que nos hace importantes, eso es lo que nos hace relevantes. Eso es lo que nos hace humanos.

Bir gün taşıdığımız yük birine yardımcı olabilir. Fakat uzun süre önce, elimizde kitaplar olduğu zaman bile, onlardan çıkardığımız şeyleri kullanmadık. Ölülere sövmeye devam ettik. Bizden önce ölmüş zavallıların mezarlarına tükürmeye devam ettik. Önümüzdeki hafta, önümüzdeki ay, önümüzdeki yıl, bir sürü yalnız insanla karşılaşacağız. Bize
tr_second_half: ne yaptığımızı sordukları zaman onlara, hatırladığımızı söyleyebilirsiniz. İşte uzun vadede kazançlı olacağımız nokta burası. Bir gün, o kadar çok şey hatırlayacağız ki, tarihin en büyük buharlı kazı makinesini yaparak bütün zamanların en büyük mezarını kazıp, savaşı içine ittikten sonra üstünü örteceğiz.
